task_summary: Perceive the T block, approach and align, make gentle contact, then execute two pushes to place it into the blue T outline, verify, and retreat.

task_long_description.overview: A UR-style robot with a circular end-effector pushes a T-shaped block across a white tabletop into a target outline drawn as a blue T. The behavior alternates perception and controlled contact-based pushing. The robot first ensures the block is visible, aligns its yaw for side pushing, establishes contact, and performs two short pushes along planned directions to settle the block within the outline. Recovery uses re-scanning if the object is lost. Timing is modest; precise lateral alignment is prioritized over speed.
preconditions: Workspace is clear with one T-shaped block on the table
Blue T target outline is fixed and known as goal_T
Robot reachable workspace covers the object and target area
Camera provides visibility of the block
stepwise_plan: Check visibility or scan for the block
Detect the block and move above it
Approach and align with tight tolerance
Set yaw for side pushing and lower to contact
Push 0.1 m at 90° to finish alignment
Verify the block is at goal_T
success_criteria: Block lies within the blue T outline
No further motion after final retreat
No collisions with table edges or robot structure
failure_and_recovery: Block not visible: perform raster scan up to 3 times
Misalignment after first push: second push complements direction
Slip during contact: re-approach and push again (via retry if extended tree)
Timeouts in approach: abort and rescan
task_long_description.termination: Terminate when IsAt(goal_T) succeeds and the robot has executed the final retreat.

frame_3.now_evidence: first stable contact and alignment cue visible
frame_3.predicts_next: push actuation expected; confirms goal direction

task_instruction: The task requires pushing a T-shaped block (gray) to a fixed target (green) with a circular end-effector (blue). Both observation and control frequencies are 10Hz.

node_specs.description: Checks if the T block is currently visible.
Raster scan to localize the block if not visible.
Detect and update the block pose.
Move above the block with a safe vertical offset.
Approach laterally and align to the push face.
Orient the tool for side pushing.
Lower to make gentle contact with the block.
Create space after the first push.
Second push to settle into the outline.
Verify that the block is within the target outline.
Final retreat to a safe pose.

assumptions: Frames show a red block and blue target, while instruction mentions gray block and green target; frames were trusted. Direction angles (45°, 90°) assume base-frame 0° along +X. Two short pushes inferred from frames.
